Task Name: add the notify user subtask to the action card
Investigate: Xcode-archive step 2.3.6 succeeds, newer versions fail
Task Content:
Actual Behaviour
xcode-archive step does not filter out Wildcard certificate which does not contain capabilites needed.
âŒÂ  error: exportArchive: Provisioning profile "iOSDistribution: Wildcard" doesn't support the App Groups capability.
With Xcode archive 2.3.6 builds succeed with wildcard profiles like enterprise profiles (they don't contain any capabilities)

Expected Behaviour
the step should recognise that this is a wildcard profile and force sign the application
Steps to Reproduce
build an enterprise app and see it burn

Exaples
same app same config, only the step version differs
https://app.bitrise.io/build/ff01ef845e1625c0 <- works with 2.3.6
https://app.bitrise.io/build/74409e1bab7b1e00 <- fails with 2.5

It is an ongoing issue for the Flutter analyse tool: https://github.com/flutter/flutter/issues/20855
We could analyse the analyser log and determine the exist status based on the log, if only Info severity issues are present, do not fail.
Why should we do it?
information severity issues should not make the step failing
More details
the following build contains the analyse error, and the user had difficulties setting up the android steps as well because the platform issue.

Task Name: VDT Timeout option has to be decreased to 2700 seconds
Task Content:
Actual Behaviour
VDT steps currently fail Failed to start test: 500, error: Failed to create testing service, error: googleapi: Error 400: Given test timeout of 60 min exceeds limit of 45 min., badRequest if they run long enough, since Google recently changed the max limit of tests to 45 minutes.
Expected Behavior
Our step should be changed to reflect this value
Steps to Reproduce
You can reproduce it by running a VDT step longer than 45 minutes ğŸ¤”
How to solve:
Release a new step version with the new limits
Update the testing addon to do not accept more Timeout then the valid options
Comments:
[{"text":"Waiting for review: https://github.com/bitrise-io/addons-firebase-testlab/pull/55
","by":"laszlo.szucs@bitrise.io","assigned":false,"date":"6/5/2019, 4:51:15 PM GMT+2","resolved":"N/A"},{"text":"for Android https://github.com/bitrise-steplib/steps-virtual-device-testing-for-android/pull/45
","by":"sandor.feher@bitrise.io","assigned":false,"date":"5/31/2019, 1:05:01 PM GMT+2","resolved":"N/A"},{"text":"for iOS https://github.com/bitrise-steplib/steps-virtual-device-testing-for-ios/pull/11
","by":"sandor.feher@bitrise.io","assigned":false,"date":"5/31/2019, 1:02:06 PM GMT+2","resolved":"N/A"},{"text":"Consensus:
Add timeout validation in iOS & Android VDT steps
Change description to reflect the new limit
Update the add-on server to alway fall back to the allowed maximum
","by":"daniel@bitrise.io","assigned":false,"date":"5/30/2019, 2:18:44 PM GMT+2","resolved":"N/A"},{"text":"Google decreased the maximum timeout value to 2700 seconds (from 3600), and the API calls made to Firebase fails in case of using higher value than 2700 seconds.

Need to set the timeout input's  DESCRIPTION for both steps, as it is misleading for the users (check the API if both platform is affected), and also need to have a step input validation for this. (To not to let the users use a higher value than 2700 seconds.

Need to think about:
If we change the step, the change will be available in the latest step version only, and in any other step version user still will have the same problem, it is a fact that the users no need to lock for previous versions as there were no huge major changes recently. So most likely the should be able to use the latest version in any case.
We might can set this maximum limit validation in the addon server itself, however the addon server won't be able to respond back to the users that another value will be used instead of the one they set, except if the server returns an error which would fail the step the same way. One positive point beside of this that previously the Firebase API did not validate the timeout value, it simply capped to their maximum without returning error. (So if you set 5000 then it were running with 3600 automatically, without error) We could continue to use the same logic.
","by":"tamas.papik@bitrise.io","assigned":false,"date":"5/30/2019, 11:00:55 AM GMT+2","resolved":"N/A"}]

Task Name: Android scanner is not asking for variant
Task Content:
Actual Behaviour
When a user scans a project on our scanner, he won't receive a question about which variant he wants to build/test.
Expected Behaviour
We should show our brand new user_input_optional option view so they can type the one they want or leave it empty.
Steps to Reproduce
scan any android project
wait for the question

To achieve this we need to have a small refactor in our scanner to switch to the new scanner option type selector.

Implementation details:
Merge the new option model: https://github.com/bitrise-core/bitrise-init/pull/136/files
After the PR merge, use this method: https://github.com/bitrise-core/bitrise-init/pull/136/files#diff-f021d6f4671f583780a9d59e45ae2940R85 to set input types for all android options, for example: 
https://github.com/bitrise-core/bitrise-init/blob/master/scanners/android/android.go#L63
from:
variantOption := models.NewOption(VariantInputTitle, VariantInputEnvKey)
to: 
variantOption := models.NewOption(VariantInputTitle, VariantInputEnvKey).SetType(models.TypeOptionalUserInput)

Migrate all the android scanner's option model, to the new option model.

After that we can create the first option (variant), which is an optional selector type input (user either do not specify the input [specify an empty value] /Â choose from a given list of options).
Variant option was user_input and now it need to be user_input_optional.

Task Content:
Use case(s)
Unity is the most used framework to build mobile games, so we want to provide official support for it.
Description
The research should answer the following questions:
How can we make license activation easy for the users, both for free and premium Unity users?
What tools are needed to be able to build Unity apps? Which of these can we preinstall?
What steps will the team need to create and/or modify for Unity support?
What needs to be changed in the Scanner?
What files/directories can we cache for Unity builds to achieve optimum performance?
Is there any special output that Unity projects generate beside the executable artifacts?
Is there any special hardware requirement to run Unity builds in a stable, reliable manner? 
Additional resources / research (optional)
Research doc: https://app.nuclino.com/Bitrise/Projects/WIP-Unity-Platform-Support-7454f8ea-9573-464e-a14e-14dd0c8cb791

The feature owner is: Tomi

Task Content:
What should we do?
We should investigate which files/folders worth to be cached for an Android project.

At the end of the investigation should have a proposal about which dependency related files and which build related files needs to be included in the cache.
Why should we do it?
Our current Android cache solution was implemented a year ago, several things has changed since that time.
More details
The dependencies only and all (dependencies + build files) cache level split seems to be ok, we just need to make sure the right files are included in these cache categories.

The dependency download takes the most time, while we are not sure about the build file cache mechanism , thats why we separated these logics. It is 'safe' to cache dependencies, and it improves the most. While build file cache can improve slightly more (as an addition to the deps_only cache), but can be unreliable.
Checklists: {"Creator Checklist":["Have you set a priority?","Have you set the correct Location?"]}
Comments:
[{"text":"Created Nuclino page for further documenting findings: https://app.nuclino.com/Bitrise/Tooling/WIP-Android-caching-and-Bitrise-5a7e8c64-f025-4445-bb3d-6297c0575bb6
","by":"laszlo.szucs@bitrise.io","assigned":false,"date":"6/3/2019, 2:18:36 PM GMT+2","resolved":"N/A"},{"text":"Can you add doc page listing the current implememntation's cached paths (or a link to the source file where it is implemented)
","by":"laszlo.pusok@bitrise.io","assigned":false,"date":"6/3/2019, 1:37:27 PM GMT+2","resolved":"N/A"},{"text":"Waiting for presenting findings.
","by":"laszlo.szucs@bitrise.io","assigned":false,"date":"5/31/2019, 5:17:37 PM GMT+2","resolved":"N/A"},{"text":"I did not find any change in the directories since our cache was implemented, however, there can be Gradle version specific changes that occurred, that cause issues if the user uses an old or buggy version. Also, on Aug 27, 2018 Gradle 4.10 was released which does periodic cleanup of unused files.

The following questions came to my mind, needing further investigation:
What if the user uploads a cache archive using version 4.1 and then upgrades to 4.2? Will the old, version specific cache files be carried on?
What if I donâ€™t build project for a long period? If periodical check marks them as unused, they might be recreated, which means they are cached and downloaded from Bitrise, but they are recreated nevertheless (resulting in longer builds, which is exactly what users reported in some cases, one of them in fact experiencing it after taking a holiday).
How does our cache work with Gradle versions prior 4.10?

I found a handy flag, which might be used to dissect our Gradle build cache:
 
 gradle compileJava -Dorg.gradle.caching.debug=true --build-cache
 
 It will result in a verbose log of the Gradle build cache.Â 

Gradle Enterprise has a built-in functionality similar to our cache (a remote build cache), which might be stabler because it implicitly keeps up with any Gradle updates.

","by":"laszlo.szucs@bitrise.io","assigned":false,"date":"5/31/2019, 5:15:56 PM GMT+2","resolved":"N/A"},{"text":"we can not agree if this involves the Bitrise cache implementation or not.
","by":"krisztian.godrei@bitrise.io","assigned":false,"date":"1/29/2019, 2:23:18 PM GMT+1","resolved":"N/A"},{"text":"android build cache: https://developer.android.com/studio/build/build-cache

android cache in gradle: https://guides.gradle.org/using-build-cache/#caching_android_projects

gradle dependency cache: https://docs.gradle.org/current/userguide/dependency_cache.html

gradle build cache: https://guides.gradle.org/using-build-cache/
","by":"laszlo.szucs@bitrise.io","assigned":false,"date":"1/28/2019, 3:18:20 PM GMT+1","resolved":"N/A"},{"text":"Convert this to an issue

Task Content:
Actual Behaviour
Currently the 0.10 version of the Flutter Installer step seems to fail with 
Switching channels failed with error code 1.
ï¿½[31;1mFailed to set flutter channel, error: exit status 1ï¿½[0m
|                                                                         
Expected Behaviour
the step installs the latest version of flutter
Steps to Reproduce
start a workflow with flutter install it will fail

https://app.bitrise.io/build/7beb5138565be3c9 <- this is mine
https://app.bitrise.io/build/ee4271b1ea5e6e3f <- the build the user reported

 

Seems like a git pull error:
https://stackoverflow.com/questions/14318234/how-do-i-ignore-an-error-on-git-pull-about-my-local-changes-would-be-overwritt

The branch switch works fine.
But the git pull would change the previously cloned files, and that cause the problem :face_with_monocle:
https://github.com/bitrise-steplib/bitrise-step-flutter-installer/blob/bd585b116b975e6a0c626cb04c5e5b1de8035e5f/main.go#L64

 
Suggested solution:

Before the Flutter install step would call the update. We have to make sure that the repository is in clean state. We could reset the git installation repository and do the fetch then.

Or check if removing the whole repository and cloning it again would be faster.

Task Content:
What should we do?
Currently, we save temporary files on the disk at a centralised place. We have to come up with a solution to clean up these files in case of an unfinished app.

modify codesigndoc to be able to auto upload (store the output in a tmp dir, remove the files after the upload) to Bitrise and to be able to accept the personal access token
use the scanner's exported methods to generate the bitrise.yml
registration progress file is currently saved on the disk as well
Why should we do it?
To not store unnecessary files on the disk.
More details

Task Name: test with a local website instance
Investigate: Android re-sign for publishing on Ship add-on
Task Content:
Use case(s)
As a PM I want to be able to submit my app to the Play Store without the need to run a full build again after testers have approved the app.
Description
Research possibility of exporting a new, re-signed by (release) APK then publish to Play Store. 
What type of APK/AAB can and should be exported re-signed?
What additional API endpoints do we need to create for Ship or Bitrise? 
What info does the user need to provide in advance in Ship settings for re-signing?
The process needs to be async
Bitrise Ship -> worker -> resign & upload
Additional resources/research (optional)
Full specification of Ship: https://app.nuclino.com/Bitrise/Projects/Phase-1-details-and-user-stories-46e582d9-a3da-42bf-8e45-b3f59f33d583
Designs for Ship (Publish flow is WIP): https://zpl.io/bzqRkrz

Task Content:
Actual Behaviour
This card is the output of the investigation card   
"Reccomend adding a gem install bundler to the step, if the issue persists, is not a step issue."
In case if a new ruby version is installed through rbenv (https://github.com/rbenv/rbenv/issues/285#issuecomment-11843413,
https://github.com/rbenv/rbenv/issues/576#issuecomment-39901621), or the current rbenv bin path (`~/.rbenv/versions/2.5.3/bin/bundle`) becomes messed up, bundle will not be found by the shim (that prints out the error message): `/Users/lpusok/.rbenv/shims/bundle`
rbenv: bundle: command not found


The `bundle' command exists in these Ruby versions:
Â 2.3.5
Expected Behaviour
Do not print error message.
Steps to Reproduce
Install bundler for a ruby version installed via rbenv. bundle command will execute.
Install new bundler version, switch to it as global ruby version with rbenv.
bundle command will print error message. (`rbenv: bundle: command not found

More info
Add gem install bundler
to the step logic.
The version change can be solved by gem install bundler if rbenv config is messed up, that may not be enough. Just deleting the binary from the path ~/.rbenv/versions/2.5.3/bin/bundle is fxed by gem install.
Examples of corruption:
https://stackoverflow.com/a/52977808
https://stackoverflow.com/a/28059501

New version example:
```
/test â¯â¯â¯ rbenv global 2.5.3
~/test â¯â¯â¯ bundle install
rbenv: bundle: command not found

Â 2.3.5
```

Task Name: Scanner: outdated step versions - update them to support Testing Add-On
Task Content:
Actual Behaviour
When a user scans a new project on Bitrise.io, they will receive workflows containing outdated step versions, which doesn't contain Testing Add-on feature.
Expected Behaviour
When the user scans a project on Bitrise.io they should receive an updated workflow which supports Testing Add-On features by default.
Steps to Reproduce
Scan a project
See that at least the Deploy to Bitrise.io step is outdated

Task Name: Add public documentation to require new PR for steplib
Task Content:
What should we do?
1 PR should only contain one file (except the icon), and one change.
Require to re-create PR when addressing review concerns, this is needed to guarantee that the last (correct) tag/version of the step source repository is referenced
One PR should only contain one step.

Add this new section to the steplib's README.md.
Why should we do it?
More details

Task Name: Out of the box Cache support for Flutter projects
Task Content:
Use case(s)
After onboarding a Flutter app I'd like caching to be in place, configured automatically, instead of me adding the cache steps and figuring out what to cache for my Flutter project.
How it should work for the user
Onboard a new Flutter app
Done (with caching configured)

The point is what you DONT have to do, something that you have to do today: preparing the cache config.
Additional resources/research (optional)
https://speakerdeck.com/matsue/optimize-flutter-workflow-on-bitrise

Refined:
flutter deps + cocoapods (if any) + carthage (if any) + gradle deps (just like android build does)

Shared package for collecting cache: https://github.com/bitrise-io/go-steputils/blob/master/cache/cache.go

Flutter Build step:
Don't cache the build tool, but cache the dependencies. So no for flutter install and yes to flutter deps. Find where these files are downloaded and add them to the cacheable paths. 
Beside of the above update Flutter step to export platform relevant cache paths. (for example for cocoapods, carthage etc, you can use the dependency steps as a reference)

After the Flutter step is updated, update the step version in the scanner so the latest version will be updated for the generated workflows. https://github.com/bitrise-io/bitrise-init/blob/master/steps/const.go#L236-L262

Task Name: Sign APK step: rename apk_path input and the step
Task Content:
Use case(s)
"A new app publishing format is available in 3.2 version to deploy customized apk to users using Google playâ€™s dynamic delivery system.Studio will generate .aab file that will be uploaded on playstore and it will create many different versions of app based on chip architecture, screen size and locale."
Description
rename the input: apk_file to android_app and the default input value becomes: $BITRISE_APK_PATH
$BITRISE_AAB_PATH 
How to deprecate an input:
remove the old input from the step.yml but do not remove it from the step's code so the new and the old inputs are working together for a short period(this way we are not creating breaking changes)
if the step detects that the user still uses the old input key print a warning to tell the users that this input support will be completely removed in the next versions
rename the step to Android Sign

https://github.com/bitrise-steplib/steps-sign-apk
Generic info why these changes are required
This question need to be split into two main parts, inputs and outputs. 

The users should see 3, type defined inputs in our steps:
apk_path (this input should only accept APKs, default input value usually should be $BITRISE_APK_PATH)
aab_path (this input should only accept AABs, default input value usually should be $BITRISE_AAB_PATH)
android_app (this input should accept both APKs and AABs, default input value usually should be the list of $BITRISE_APK_PATH and $BITRISE_AAB_PATH)

Outputs:
$BITRISE_APK_PATH (only APKs can be exported to this env)
$BITRISE_AAB_PATH (only AABs can be exported to this env)

If the step can handle both APK and AAB seamlessly in one input, the input is renamed to android_app and shall default to both $BITRISE_APK_PATH and $BITRISE_AAB_PATH separated by a newline. Otherwise, it will be named respectively.
If the step can produce both APK and AAB, it will output it into two separate vars respectively.
